title: Erdős Problem #312: Subset Sum of Unit Fractions
description: Does there exist c > 0 such that for K > 1, every large multiset with Σ(1/n) > K has a subset summing to within exp(-cK) of 1?

overview.historicalContext: Originally posed by Erdős and Graham [ErGr80], this problem explores the precision of subset sums of unit fractions. Erdős and Graham proved a weaker polynomial bound (c/K²), but the exponential bound (exp(-cK)) remains open. This exemplifies the gap between polynomial and exponential rates in combinatorial number theory.
overview.problemStatement: Does there exist a constant c > 0 such that, for any K > 1, whenever A is a sufficiently large finite multiset of positive integers with Σ_{n ∈ A} 1/n > K, there exists a subset S ⊆ A with 1 - exp(-cK) < Σ_{n ∈ S} 1/n ≤ 1?
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines the subset sum property for unit fractions, states the main conjecture with exponential bound, and includes the known Erdős-Graham result with polynomial bound. Comparison theorems show the exponential bound is strictly stronger.
keyInsights: The problem asks about 'precision' of subset sums approaching 1
Exponential bound exp(-cK) is much stronger than polynomial c/K²
Large total sum (> K) ensures many possible subset sums
Unit fractions have irregular structure unlike powers of 2
Harmonic numbers provide natural examples with Σ 1/n ≈ ln(n)

sections.title: The Problem
sections.content: Given a multiset of positive integers whose reciprocals sum to more than K, can we always find a subset whose sum is very close to 1? The conjectured error bound is exp(-cK), exponentially small in K.

sections.title: Erdős-Graham Theorem
sections.content: A weaker version is known: the polynomial bound c/K² suffices. This means we can always find a subset summing to within c/K² of 1. The gap is the transition from polynomial to exponential.

sections.title: Exponential vs Polynomial
sections.content: For large K, exp(-cK) << c/K². So the conjectured exponential bound gives much tighter approximation to 1. Proving this requires understanding the fine structure of subset sums.

sections.title: Harmonic Numbers
sections.content: The canonical example is A = {1, 2, ..., n} with sum H_n ≈ ln(n) + γ. As n grows, we get arbitrarily large K, and the problem asks about finding near-1 sums.

conclusion.summary: The problem asks whether subset sums of unit fractions can achieve exponentially precise approximations to 1. The polynomial version is solved, but the exponential conjecture remains open.
conclusion.implications: Resolution would impact our understanding of the arithmetic of unit fractions and potentially have applications to approximation algorithms for subset sum problems.
openQuestions: Does the exponential bound exp(-cK) hold?
What is the optimal constant c?
Are there connections to the Egyptian fraction representation of rationals?
